title: Alphabets and Sounds
content: Pupils learn the 26 letters of the alphabet (A–Z) and their sounds. Singing the alphabet song and matching letters with pictures makes learning fun. Letters are the foundation of spelling and vocabulary. Children should practice both uppercase (A, B, C) and lowercase (a, b, c) letters daily.
takehome: 1. Sing the ABC song twice every day. 2. Point out letters on street signs or books. 3. Trace letters in sand or with chalk. 4. Match letters with objects at home. 5. Practice writing 5 letters neatly.
exercises: Write A to Z in your notebook.
Circle vowels in this set: A, B, E, C, O.
Match the letter A with an Apple picture.
Say the sound of letters: B, D, M.
Color the letters A, B, and C.

title: Two-Letter Words
content: Simple two-letter words are the first step in reading and spelling. They help children build confidence in forming words quickly. Pupils should learn to sound out and recognize these short words in books and around them.
takehome: 1. Read 5 two-letter words aloud at home. 2. Spell 3 words before bedtime. 3. Write each word 3 times. 4. Look for two-letter words in a storybook. 5. Use them in sentences like 'I am 6'.
exercises: Write the words: am, be, go.
Fill in the missing letter: a_, g_, b_.
Circle the correct spelling: go / gu.

title: Three-Letter Words
content: Pupils learn CVC words (consonant-vowel-consonant). These words improve spelling and help children start reading simple sentences. Children should practice sounding each letter and blending them to form words.
takehome: 1. Read 5 three-letter words aloud. 2. Write and spell 3 words daily. 3. Use them in a short story. 4. Show a picture and spell the word. 5. Play with word cards at home.
exercises: Fill the blanks: c_t, h_t, s_n.
Circle the vowel in: bat, mat, hat.

title: Rhyming Words
content: Rhyming words end with the same sound. They make reading and poetry fun while helping pupils notice word patterns. Practicing rhymes also boosts listening and spelling skills.
takehome: 1. Sing nursery rhymes with rhyming words. 2. Create rhyming pairs with family. 3. Write 3 rhyming words daily. 4. Circle rhymes in a storybook. 5. Play 'find a rhyme' game with friends.
exercises: Write 3 words that rhyme with cat.

title: Sight Words
content: Sight words are common words pupils should memorize without sounding out. They make reading smoother and faster. Pupils will see them often in books and daily use.
takehome: 1. Write 5 sight words daily. 2. Read sight words with a parent. 3. Point out sight words in a storybook. 4. Spell sight words aloud. 5. Use them in short sentences.
exercises: Circle the sight word: cat, the, bat.
Underline sight words in 'I go to school'.

title: Plural Words
content: Plural words show more than one of something. Pupils learn to add -s or -es to make plurals. This skill improves vocabulary and grammar.
takehome: 1. Write 3 plural words daily. 2. Use plural words in a sentence. 3. Spot plurals in storybooks. 4. Count toys and write plurals. 5. Practice spelling plurals aloud.
exercises: Draw 3 apples 🍎 and write the plural.

title: Opposite Words
content: Opposite words (antonyms) have different meanings. Learning opposites helps children describe things better and grow vocabulary.
takehome: 1. Learn 5 opposites daily. 2. Say opposites aloud. 3. Play 'opposite game' with family. 4. Match opposites in books. 5. Write 2 sentences with opposites.
exercises: Draw sun ☀️ and moon 🌙 and label as opposites.

title: Synonyms
content: Synonyms are words with the same meaning. Learning them helps pupils understand and use richer vocabulary.
takehome: 1. Learn 3 synonym pairs daily. 2. Use synonyms in sentences. 3. Circle synonyms in books. 4. Play synonym match with family. 5. Write 2 synonyms on flashcards.

title: Compound Words
content: Compound words are formed by joining two words. They are fun and expand a child’s vocabulary.
takehome: 1. Write 2 compound words daily. 2. Break words into parts. 3. Use compound words in stories. 4. Spot them in reading books. 5. Draw a rainbow 🌈 and write the word.

title: Simple Sentences
content: Children use learned words to form sentences. Sentences should be short, clear, and meaningful. This helps reading and writing skills.
takehome: 1. Write 2 sentences daily. 2. Read sentences aloud. 3. Use sight words in sentences. 4. Make sentences with family names. 5. Practice writing on lined paper.
exercises: Draw and write: I eat food 🍲.
